SlideShow.Title: Slide show: Canalith repositioning procedure
SlideShow.Abstract: See the steps of the Canalith repositioning procedure — treatment for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

Slide.Caption:
The canalith repositioning procedure can treat benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which causes dizziness when you move your head. The procedure consists of head maneuvers that move particles in your inner ear — which cause dizziness — to a part of your ear where they won't.

Depending on your doctor's preferences, you may wear an infrared imaging device over your eyes during the canalith repositioning procedure. This helps your doctor examine your eyes during each maneuver, although it isn't necessary for successful treatment.

In the first step of the canalith repositioning procedure, your doctor or a trained professional helps you recline and turn your head to a 45-degree angle. The maneuvers shown here are for one type of BPPV, experienced on the left side in this person.
Slide.Title: Step 1: Moving to a reclining position
Slide.ImageAltText: Step 1 of the canalith repositioning procedure

Slide.Caption: In step 2 of the canalith repositioning procedure, your doctor or a trained professional helps you turn your head to a 90-degree angle.
Slide.Title: Step 2: Turning your head to a 90-degree angle
Slide.ImageAltText: Step 2 of the canalith repositioning procedure

Slide.Caption: In step 3 of the canalith repositioning procedure, your doctor or a trained professional helps you roll onto your nonsymptomatic side and holds your head at a slightly downward angle.
Slide.Title: Step 3: Rolling onto your side
Slide.ImageAltText: Step 3 of the canalith repositioning procedure

Slide.Caption: During the fourth and final step of the canalith repositioning procedure, your doctor or a trained professional helps you sit upright with your head tilted downward.
Slide.Title: Step 4: Returning to a sitting position
Slide.ImageAltText: Step 4 of the canalith repositioning procedure
